item.title: Convergence of Sequences Given a Quadratic Sum Condition
item.description:
Let $(u_n)$ and $(v_n)$ be two real sequences such that

$$ u_n^2+ u_n v_n + v_n^2 \xrightarrow[n\to+\infty] {}0.$$

Prove that the sequences $(u_n)$ and $(v_n)$ converge to 0.

Show Answer:
We have $$0\le (u_n+v_n)^2= u_n^2+2u_n v_n+ v_n^2\le 2(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0.$$ Hence $u_n+v_n \xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$. Also $$u_n v_n= (u_n+v_n)^2 -(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$$ so $$u_n^2+v_n^2= 2(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)-(u_n+v_n)^2\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$$ which allows to conclude that $u_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$ and $v_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$.

item.title: Divergence of Harmonic Series and Sequence Behavior at Infinity
item.description:
Let $(H_n)$ the sequence defined for $n\in \mathbb{N}$ by $$H_n= \sum_{k=1}^n \frac 1k.$$

  1. Prove that $H_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.
  2. Let $(u_n)$ a sequence such that $n(u_{n+1}-u_n)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}1$. Prove that $u_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.
Show Answer:
1. Knowing $\ln(1+x)\le x$, we have $$\frac1k\ge \ln\left(1+\frac1k\right)=\ln(k+1)-\ln k$$ so $$H_n\ge \sum_{k=1}^n \ln(k+1)-\ln k= \ln(n+1)$$ and then $H_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.

2. There exists $N\in \mathbb{N}$ such that for all $n\ge N$, $$n(u_{n+1}-u_{n})\ge 1/2.$$ Hence $$ u_{n+1}-u_{N}\ge \sum_{k=N}^n u_{k+1}-u_{k}\ge \frac12 \sum_{k=N}^n\frac1k= \frac12(H_{n}-H_{N-1})\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$$ and then $u_{n}\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.
